reviewText:
I started off with a tiny, one-room bungalow in a new neighbourhood. I had no job. I had no friends. All I had was my sole aspiration: to become a Forensics Specialist - Dynamic DNA Profiler. I spent every evening alone, playing chess into the early hours of the morning. I would paint random images throughout the day on my easel, stopping only to sate my appetite, or occasionally wash my bodily odour away. I didn't talk to anyone. I didn't need anyone. I just needed this job. I was going to be the best. And then that day came. I had reached the pinnacle of my profession. Finally I could stop worrying about my career and enjoy the finer things in life. But being at the top is perhaps the loneliness place you can be. I still had no friends. No lover. No relations of my own. I tried going out to community lots but by this time I was old and the youngsters found me creepy and odd. I once again found myself spending the days alone in my home, trying to be the best at everything. I'll show them! I don't need anybody! I've come this far on my own! But, whereas time had once been my greatest ally, it had now become my sole enemy. Yes, I was the best at all things. But I had no one to share it with. I sat alone in the place I had once called home, surrounded by all of my beautiful creations, and I felt even more miserable than at the start of it all.

Now I'm going to try out this game.

10/10

reviewText: I love the Sims 3, I find it extremely fun and addictive. Now you're probably wondering why the big red thumbs down? Well... First of all, the game costs 400$ for all the DLC and there's Micro-transactions! Micro-transactions should not be in games I pay for or in single player games! This is a complete waste of money, were I can buy about 30 games with $400 rather than getting a bunch of DLC that are a complete waste of money. I don't mind buying/paying for DLC but when I buy a game, and I have to pay for extra content to get the full experience and it will cost me $400 and I have already bought the game and if I want to have couches, fridges, clothes, expansion packs, etc, it will cost real money, this just makes me question how stupid does EA think we are? I would recommend buying the game, but the DLC will make the game actually a lot better, so its recommended to buy the game on sale and pick it up for about $100 I sure as hell thought the game was fun and had a lot of things to do, but paying huge amounts of cash into a game is way too much for me and pretty sure for anyone else.

reviewText:
I find it extremelly hard to recommend this game to anyone.

I got it for my girlfriend; rather, I got an 1/8th of this game for my girlfriend. The full game, DLC and all, is roughly $420, microtransactions included. I can't imagine that production costs were so incredibly high that EA needed to charge me an entire paycheck to play a decent, addictive (but far from extraordinary) life simulator. I didn't know that I could hate EA anymore than I already did, but I do.

The fact that there is a Sims 4 with a similar business model means that taking advantage of its customers seems to be a viable way for EA to make money. I urge everyone to spend as little on this game as possible. Hell, just torrent the game. It's single player, after all.

reviewText:
If you need to burn a few hours and have fun doing it, then this game is perfect for you. While the base game only has the basic game content, you can still spend hours building houses, making your Sims successful in life or hey, even killing them if that's what you're into. Each expansion adds hours of awesome stuff to lose yourself in, whether it be tons of new jobs with Ambitions or new types of characters with Supernatural, each one adds it's own little something.

While the game is incredibly addicting, it also has lots of bugs. Some bugs have been around since the start, like the game crashing (happens mostly when you haven't saved for several hours and you just finished building your dream home), others only turn up when you start installing expansions or custom content, like the strechy babies and the hand-bowl (not actually sure where this comes from).

So, yes, I recommend the game, but just be prepared for glitches, crashes and a slight addiction to new content.

reviewText:
In The Sims 3 you create and control simulated people and watch them live their lives. It's a good life simulator. Perhaps a little too good, because just like with real life, it will destroy your hopes and dreams.

When The Sims 3 works it can be a fun game, but unfortunately that isn't very often. The game is notorious for lagging, stuttering, freezing, crashing, and having all sorts of other game-breaking bugs. If you don't believe me, just Google it. I've spent more time trying to fix the game than actually playing it.

The Sims 3 becomes frustrating even before you start a game. Depending on your system, and which DLC you have installed, it can take several minutes to several hours just to get into the actual game. But this is mostly the fault of the game itself, as even high-end systems experience the same problems running The Sims 3. In fact, the loading times are so long that the developers added a barely functioning mini-game to play while you wait for the game to load. The Sims 3 has THE WORST loading times I've ever experienced in a game, and that's saying a lot.

Speaking of worst, The Sims 3 also has THE WORST camera controls I've ever experienced in a game. The camera controls aren't just clunky and clumsy. They slide around even after you let go of the button, causing the camera to overshoot the intended target. Other times it feels like the game is actively fighting back at every key press, pushing the camera in a different direction from the one you're moving it in.

To make matters even worse, you CANNOT customize the controls in The Sims 3. Not at all. This isn't even a console port. This game was designed for the PC, yet you cannot customize the controls. There is no option to do so in the options menu. There isn't even an option to look at the keyboard controls so you know which button does what. And the Q key quits the game, so be careful.

To add insult to injury, EA has made The Sims 3 one of it's biggest cash cows. Not only are there numerous over-priced expansion packs, and even more garbage that EA wants you to buy from their online store, but they constantly remind you of these products via in-game pop-up advertisements. That's right... Pop-up advertisements in an offline single-player game. It's utterly disgusting. And when the DLC does go on sale, it's usually cheaper to buy directly from EA's online store rather than from Steam.

I just can't understand how any professional game designer or publisher thought it was acceptable to release a game in this broken state. The Sims 3 has been out since 2009 and these issues have never been fixed. And now The Sims 4 is coming out, so I doubt The Sims 3 will be getting better anytime soon.

EA and the developers of The Sims 3 should feel nothing but shame over this poorly-coded excuse for a game. It's no wonder that EA keeps winning the award for the worst company in America. Don't make the same mistake I did and pay actual money to play The Sims 3. I cannot recommend it to anyone unless you are a masochist.

reviewText: As much as I'd like to recommend this, it probably isn't worth your money. reviewText:
The Sims 3 without any expansion packs... Is buggy, frustrating, slow and really really wants to sell you additional content with real money with every minute you play it.

When something glitches up and renders your game broken, frequently the only way to fix it is to delete your saves and start all over again, completely undoing the work and time you invested in your sims and your town.

And yet, still, I have not come across another game that offers what The Sims franchise offers in terms of an engaging, engrossing and detailed life simulator.

In short, The Sims is like an unfaithful lover who does what no other lover you know does, but always breaks your heart. Really all I can recommend is not getting hooked in the first place.

reviewText:
This is a complete review for ts3 that will explain everything from buying the game to playing the game. Pease read:)

- Important quick info about my relationship with ts3 : I have all the dlcs, and most of the worlds from ts3 store, which I have bought on origin, before I was aware of steam. I have played over 4500 hours offline (due to limited internet). I own all the dlcs, and most of the store stuff.

- Should I get ts4 or ts3? : I currently own ts4 with 1 dlc. Below are the pros and cons for ts3 and ts4.

- Ts4 pros

1. Your sim can multitask
2. Their mood effects them more in their everday lives than in ts3.
3. CAS (create a sim) has better graphics, but your sims are less customizable than in ts3.
4. Creating your house is quicker when it comes to building walls, foundations, etc.

- Ts4 cons

1. The world is realitively small, and their is only a few small lots you can build on.
2. Their are no cars, and as of now they have still neglected to add toddlers to the game.
3. Their are more loading screens than on ts3 for xbox 360.
4. You can not see where your sim works, and traits are limited.

- Ts3 pros

1. Open world, you can edit every lot .
2. CAS comes with a lot of stuff to make your Sim family and simself.
3. The only loading screens in the game only pop up when you go to another town.
4.  Their is over 60 traits with just the basgame, so you can truly play with life.
5. Houses and community lots are fully customizable, and their is no limit other than your budget when building.

-  Ts3 cons

1. The game is addicting, and the possibilities are endless.
2. You can't walk on water.

- When buying the game should I buy on steam or origin? :

It is best to buy ts3 game series on steam, so that you can keep your favorite games at your favorite place. When you buy on steam some of the major benefits, are the sales and that when you buy ts3 on steam you can register the same game on origin, which virtually gives you 2 for the price of 1. When you decide you want to get the game I would recommend you save your money for the steam summer, or winter sale, so that of you don't like it, you don't have as big of a loss.

Now this is what I have to say about the game itself :

-  What does it mean when the game says Stuff pack vs. Expansion pack?

- There are 2 types of dlcs they sell for ts3 and ts4, stuff packs and expansion packs.

- Stuff packs - which normally come with more furniture and clothes.(occasionly some traits)

- Expansion packs - which comes with loads of new game content for your sims, and almost always comes with a new world for your Sims. Plus it adds a lot more stuff to CAS and build and buy mode.

- Why are their so many negative reviews on the dlcs? :

Most of the reviews for the dlcs are of people who never truly looked into the game about whether or not they wanted to buy it, and the rest are mostly compliants about their pc not working. (Which is not because of ts3) This game runs great with all the dlcs for me, and all the dlcs enhance the gameplay with different chracteristics that I cant live without.

What of game play is this game? :

It is not just building houses, and creating sims, its meant for you to show your creativity, and play with life.

I would recommend you just buy the basegame or the game bundle to start with, and see if you enjoy the game! If you are also on the short side of cash, check out the tsr website for loads of free cas and house stuff.

Must read!!  ‚û° Do not think this game is innapropiate, because of inappropoate mods. Their is no nudity in this game, so please dont mess up this game with bad mods! The humor is great, the playing is great, and the friends are great,

- On the funny side : This is what happens when I play ts3 :  First 5 hours, I spend making my sims,  2 hours on my house, 1 hour in-game, and already my wife ended up starting an affair with the neighbor. I ended up getting divorced within an hour, and eventually died when trying to fix the dishwasher.      11/10

reviewText:
As always. The Sims 3 is a fantastic simulation game where you can create your sim, get married, become the president who raises a son who ghost busts on the weekend. Lock the president in a basement to die during a TV repair and then live out your daughter's life as a professional chef.

The Sims has always been a great series and one of EA's staples. But I give it a thumbs down, just like I'll give any Sims game a thumbs down because you are basically paying for 1/20 of the game. The other 19 parts arriving in DLC downloads that cost the same amount as the base game EACH. At the time of this review, the game is $19.99. Round that to 20 and multiply by 20 and if you want the full game... you'll be paying a whopping $400.

I love the Sims. I truly do, but I do not recommend giving money to this company. Not when they expect their consumers to dish out 400 dollars for a single game. It's base is playable, of course... but it's not worth it when all of these $20 DLC's are taunting you along the way.

First Hour

- Sim receives oppurtunity and Second Promotion
48 hours Later
- Computer Dies
- Player Realizes Addiction to game
- Player decides to take a break and play shorter next time
Next Hour
- Player Logs on to Sims 3
120 hours Later
- Computer Dies
- Player writes Review

10/10 Would Buy Again :)

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
The Sims 3 is a life-simulation-sandbox developed by a division of EA known as The Sims Studio, the Sims 3 was released 2009.
The general idea is to progress your character/family through the game by building/buying a house, purchasing items to supply your Sims basic needs; Hunger, Social, Bladder, Hygiene, Energy, and Fun.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: I personally admire Sandbox games because of the flexibility you have with story, and game elements. Each person will have their own personal story playing through the Sims. (If you don't care to hear the story of my first Sims game: Skip to Gameplay)

I created a Sim that looked like me, and proceeded to move into a house and begin to work on building my life. After getting my first job, the car for work showed up earlier then I expected, and I sadly didn't have time to eat my Waffles, so I left them on the street and went to work.
After putting in a hard eight hour work day, I returned to my waffles on the street. (I had watched them the whole time from my above view. I watched them... mocking me.) Now, any sane person would know not to eat waffles left on the street for eight hours, but I'm not sane, I ate those suckers after getting home. Then proceeded to vomit in the toilet for the next few hours.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=511831776

Eventually I became familiar with the weird 3D controls, married a lady who turned into a grandma the day after we were married ( *Condescending tone* Being the noble man that I am, I reloaded my save file. In my defense, she didn't tell me she was three times my age when we dated!)

After getting married, becoming the leader of the free world, and having a kid... I died of old age. This is when I realized my terrible mistake; I shouldn't have made an avatar that looked like me. Eventually My son brought me back as a ghost, but I felt wrong after seeing myself die in a video game like that.

Gameplay: It's hard to articulate how weird the controls are for The Sims 3, you can zoom in and out, rotate the camera, switch between Sims, the GUI (Graphical User Interface) isn't the weird part about the controls... It's when you're trying to learn the key-bindings, ‚Äúwhich mouse button does what‚Äù, clicking and holding the scroll wheel, among a host of other keyboard shortcuts.
It took several hours of play time to get familiar with the controls, I suspect I might have been helped or hindered with my experience working in 3D modeling programs such as 3Ds Max, Source SDK, and Blender.
There is a lot that can be said about The Sims 3 gameplay, but the best way to sum it up is that this is ‚Äúa Sims game‚Äù. This was the first Sims game I played since trying it at a friend's house when I was younger.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=511831787

Achievements: There are no Steam Achievements on the Sims 3, however if you're objective or goal oriented, there are in-game accomplishments that you can work on earning. These accomplishments are shown on your Sims 3 community profile page.

Price: This is where The Sims 3 gets sticky, and I start to get cynical... The Core game is priced at $19.99, that's an extremely fair asking price for the core game. But wait, there's more!
If you look in your furniture section within the game, there are advertisements for more furniture that you need to spend real money to unlock! (Really EA? We didn't spend enough?)
But wait, there's more! Each DLC pack (19 packs in total) costs $19.99! This is where many people start mumbling about EA having a money grubbing exploitative business model(Or maybe just me). If you do want to get the DLC for the Sims 3, it's recommended you look for bundle deals that are on sale to get the most out of your purchase.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=510203419

Conclusion: to recap, Story: flexible and unique. Gameplay: takes some time to get used to the controls if you're new to the series. Achievements: None on steam, but accomplishments in game. Price: Fair for the core game, however the marketing design is to shake you down for more money.
I recommend this game to people who enjoy simulation games, play casual games, and like building houses.

Do you like the way EA sells DLC for The Sims 3? Or do you think they should include more in the core game? Feel free to let me know in the comments, thanks for reading my review.

------Edits and updates------
Edit/Update August 1, 2015:
Punctuation correction made by Angfucious, thank you :)

reviewText:
Years ago, when the Sims 3 first came out, I hated it. It was much more complex than the Sims 2, and it was overwhelming. I became accustomed to all of the options and possibilities, however, and now it is my favorite version of the Sims! Although I like the new Create-a-Sim Mode on Sims 4 that uses click-and-drag to determine Sims' looks, I miss all of the options for hair and eye color in Sims 3. The Sims 3 also had the Create-a-Style option which allowed the player to personalize virtually anything in the game by selecting patterns and colors for it. I once made an entire house with everything inside it entirely in plaid, just because I could! And it was fun!

Another reason I love the Sims 3 the most is how the map is continuous and you can watch your sim travel from destination to destination in their car, instead of having a load scene while switching lots.

The Sims 3 also has the most career options, which I appreciate. Sims 4 really lacks variety in this area. It doesn't even have a medical career track, which was even in the first version of the Sims! The stuff packs and expansions of Sims 3 are also really fun if you have enough money and space to accommodate them. A con of the Sims 3 is that it takes more power and storage space to run it than the other versions.

reviewText:
Regardless of how I may enjoy the game in the near future when I finally get it to work, EA is a piece of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• for making the Sims a so expensive title after a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• of years. The only reason I bought it is that I don't bother with downloading pirated copies anymore and the game was on 'sale'.

Anyway apart from the absurd pricing (not even AAA titles released around 2009 still cost this much) the DLC grab is the worst I've ever seen (compared to it Payday 2 and Rome Total War II shine for their decency) and the game is so incomplete without any of them that you will have to purchase at least one, or get a cracked copy of it.

Finally the only reason I'm wasting my time writing this, really, is that as I mentioned above the game doesn't work properly. Compatibility problems with W7 and 8 are massive and the troubleshooting required is at times just too much. I've been able to play some 4 hours and after relaunching the game everything turned wrong. First the costant crashing every 10 minutes, then every 5 and finally the freezing (every 2 or so). I tried to update again my gpu drivers only to find out the game does not recognise it and pick the built in intel card (playing on a laptop). Not saying the game will never work, but like Bethesda did with FO3 a label stating there are issues with newer systems and graphic cards should be added to the store page.

After so many years few will still buy this game but for the ones considering that option, just stay way. This game is begging to be downloaded ('illegally').

Expansion Packs are like mini sequals to games. They add new features and expand upon the old ones. An example of a Sims 3 Expansion Pack would be World Adventures or Island Paradice. These two added signifigant ammounts of content to the game

reviewText:
Sims 3, for all it's faults and troubles is probably the best Sims game to date.

The open world provides a sense of immersion not achieved by earlier games.  This is a feature that was missing in previous games.

There are a wide variety of expansion packs to provide additional functionality for just about anyone.

You can pretty much play the game however you want, you can make your sim an upstanding citizen, a socialite, an excentric recluse, a crook or anything inbetween.  You can have your sims befriend everyone and be known for being nice, use them to express your darkest desires to ruin all your neighbor's lives, or even ruin their own lives if you so chose.

That is not to say the game doesn't have it's problems.   It is probably the buggiest game ever released by EA, and that includes Sim Copter and Streats of Sim City.   It is using an archaic branch of Mono which makes the Mono releases chosen by Unity3D look new, and has a severely garbage collector that leaves unnecessary cruft everywhere and instead vacates other objects from memory as soon as you leave the lot they are on.   It seems either the core programmers didn't know how to mark something as a cached asset, or just didn't bother.   Despite the size of the game, there is no attempt to use either a disk heap, or a secondary virtual memory segment to store cached assets, and until recently it didn't even support over 2GB of game memory space.


Tech support is nearly non-existant, but fortunately the game has finally stopped being update to support expansion packs, which would commonly break the game completely for older expansion packs, so there are fewer issues.

To put it simply, the game itself I give a wonderfully positive rating as a near perfect game for it's category.  It is everything a Sims game should be.  However, the backend is flawed at best, and often downright broken, while tech support is downright non-existant.   Frankly, I think EA could care less about technical support or keeping their older games functioning on newer technology, and I think recent reports of having the worst customer support in the video game industry are not only accurate, but an understatement.

Still, if you can put up with these faults, The Sims 3 is certainly worth your time and frustrations.

reviewText:
The Sims is the best life-simulation game around, hands down. I personally enjoy the Sims 3, due to the open world nature(opposed to the Sims 2, just in your house, or Sims 4, with locations, but not just one big world), and the enormous amount of add-ons that can go in to customize your game. Want retro 70s clothes? They have it. Seasons? Check on that. Pets? Hell yeah. Vampires, witches, and things that go 'bump'? You bet! With dozens of worlds, thousands of outfits(and what can only be billions of combination outfits), and hundreds of building materials/household items you can buy, this game is already incredible. But the best part is in life simulation. Every sim, no matter how much you try, will look different, act different, and have different wishes. Even minor things like having a hotdog will propel your sims into a whole new world of wishes and hopes, from cooking, to a new job, to opportunities that accompany this. A brief pass with someone at the supermarket can bloom into a relationship, a family, and any number of other possibilities. Every single playthrough is different, and that allows you to experiment as many times as you wish. Even with a single game is varies greatly day-by-day. One day, you could have an aspiring author, the next, they want to join Sunset Valley's Finest, or their worst. How they react, is up to you.


11/10 for me, endless fun, and a wide open world.

reviewText: The bad things you hear are mostly all true: gameplay can get extremely laggy, EA is not the best company when it comes to customer satisfaction, and so on and so forth. The only reason that I still recommend this game is largely because there are no equal alternatives to it: despite lag and bug issues, the content (with expansions) is massive, the possibilities are almost endless. Also, there are many mods that are not only easy to install but fix alot of the problems that EA has neglected to fix (they rather spend their time pushing out more mini expansions and developing their cash shop).

reviewText: I really enjoy the sims games, I have owned multiple expansions for the sims 3 on disk and decided to purchase the sims 3 via steam during the sale to try out some new expansions but I have noticed that there are many bugs when playing the sims through steam. The game randomly has lag spikes that the player has to wait through, usually 3 days time for the lag to go away, but will also come back, and I have had several occasions of this game crashing, or it just stops responding and I have to end it via task manager. The sims 3 is a great game but if you want to play this game, purchase it in disk form, not through steam.

reviewText:
‚ô• You can do anything.

Want to have a polygamist family? Want to roll around in money? Want to travel to Egypt, steal treasure from tombs, and have an affair?

With Sims 3, you can. If you only have the base game and none of the DLC's, you can easily get mods for the game that will add an endless amount of things: instant money, incest, custom jobs, etc. With Sims you can have the character live the life you imagine for them.

‚ô• Relationships.

This is by far why I've played Sims 3 for as many hours as I've had. In Sims 3 you can find a boyfriend, marry him, cheat with his brother, and divorce - all in the same day. Sims 3 doesn't have morals and doesn't want you to have them either.

For that reason, you can cheat as much as you want, have as many kids as you want, or embrace the single, celebrity rockstar life. If you want to have an arch nemesis and revel in kicking their trash can, you can.

Or you can be the seemly modest grandmother who writes erotic tales at night and takes care of her grandchildren, plays chess with her husband at the park, and bask in your retirement during the day.

‚ô• Everything is up to you.

From the design of the house to the look of your Sim to their likes and dislikes, you control anything and everything. You aren't limited in any area for even their needs you can control. If you use a cheat code, you can easily make their needs (hunger, sleep, etc) to 100% meaqning you'll have more time to focus on the fun aspects of their life.

With Sims, the character is entirely in your hands.

‚úò This game lags.

A lot. It's known for crashing without warning, freezing at any vital moment, and can be quite fussy to run. I've learned that when you first launch the game - DON'T DO ANYTHING. Just let it play through the cutscene and go to the main menu. Don't try to skip it, don't try to rush it.

The same goes for when it freezes and lags.

Otherwise it's going to sulk and quit on you just when your Sim becomes famous or is about to have their baby.

‚úò The base designs are...bleh.

I used to think they were amazing - the blocky hair, the ill fitting clothes, the ugly looking earrings. However once I discovered the world of mods, I learned how awful the base items are. Unfortunately installing too many mods can severely lag your game - so you'll have to be strict about which ones are worth keeping and which aren't.

‚úò There are bugs.

A lot of them. University can cause errors with assigning you to study" when you aren't enrolled in school
date: a Sim that is aging up can end up with their bones disjointed and their head all stretched
recommended: your Sim can decide they can't walk forwards because dust is in their way
hoursPlayed: etc.\n\nOverall the Sims 3 is by far the most beloved of all the games I've ever played

reviewText: I've really never written a review for a game before, so I will do my best to make this brief.  Sims 3 expands on a lot of the features from the previous installments, including adding some new features and then Electronic Arts to my surprise removed some features in this edition.  One of the features they removed that was in the Sims 2, was the ability to create new lots.  In the Sims 3 you are basically stuck with the pre-installed lots and then of course like the previous installments you have to buy all the expansions.\n\nBuying the expansions is not what bothers me. What bothers me is not being able to make my own neighborhoods and customize them to my personal tastes like I could in the second game.  I still wish I had it.  I only have the original content version so that is what my review is based on and not any of the expansions.  So I am not aware if they have changed that rule about you being able to create your own personal neighborhoods in now since later expansions have come out.  As I may or may not have read somewhere, The neighborhood creation feature is really the only thing that bugged me, other than that everything else right down to the increased character personalization options was incredible, not to mention I was rather impressed with the realism in the way the characters looked and acted.

reviewText: As someone who played a lot of Sims 2 back in the day, this game is nothing but another disappointment from EA and a prime example of how they tend to ruin franchises. Too much DLC, which in almost every case is more expensive than the base game itself. And speaking of the base game, it very much feels like it has less content in it than the base game of the Sims 2! And don't even get me started on the microtransactions, that's just disgusting and not even worth the effort of raging over.\n\nThe Sims 3 is a great game with lots of content....if you spend the $400 or so on the expansions which do nothing but add content to the game that should have either been released at launch or patched in for free later on. Sims 3 truly sets the bar for how awful microtransactions and DLC can be in a game that could have been great. At this point just wait for the Sims 4 and pray EA has learned from their mistakes....not that that's ever happened before!

reviewText: Great game, even when it's just the base game. But I simply cannot recommend it to anyone for two reasons.\nReason number ONE. It's a giant cash grab. Fortunately, you can uninstall your Steam version and re-download it through Origin for free, but I've heard that once you do, any expansions or stuff packs you get through Steam will no longer work, so don't plan on saving on sales. Seriously, EA really wants your freaking money.

reviewText:
Did you love Sims 1, Sims 2? You'll love Sims 3.

...If you want to pay this much for very little... What made the previous Sims so fun? The excessive options in clothing, furniture, etc. With Sims 3, its a little different. You'll pay 40 for the standard, and being a Sims fan you'll spend another additional 20-40 bucks for an expansion.

What you think you get? A world full of options, diversity and the start of loads of fun.
What you actually get? A hollowed out game. Lacking content compared to the earlier games. The diversity of clothing, furniture, house options, etc, its been minimized. But, EA, being as lovable as they are will give you a chance to add some of that content back.

You want to use this piece of furniture? Yes? Pay extra money.
Oh you want to make use of the different towns in your options menu? Well, better pay some more money.
This particular shirt is featured today, if you want it.. you better pay more money.

Sims 3 will use any and all means neccesary to make you pay more money for stuff that should've been in the game in the first place. You buy the 'locked' stuff with points. These points can only be purchased with real money and there is no way to earn them.

You pay for a pedigree dog, and you get an emaciated mutt.

I love Sims 3, but dont bother buying it unless its on one hell of a sale.

reviewText: This game is ridiculously huge to begin with, but for some strange reason it doesn't seem to have enough of the essential content to create a good story with the sims. I mean, in some ways it's a lot like Sims 2 (which I have loved for so many years), but in other ways, its frustratingly different. For example, in Sims 2, I felt satisfied with the game that I bought -- even though I hadn't bought any expansion packs yet. The game was able to stand on its own and impress me without having any extra content. With Sims 3, I feel this horrible dissatisfaction with the content, dispite the superior graphics and the exciting new *live* neighborhood. Oftentimes I can ignore the feeling, but some times it is dishearteningly glaring.\nThere is always this subconsious push to run back to steam and grab up more DLC so that the game can achieve some kind of tolerable level of rightness" -- almost as though EA was trying to do this on purpose. It seems awful

reviewText:
Reviews for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
---

With regard to accessibility for deaf/hoh gamers, I give The Sims 3 a 10/10.

Gameplay
The Sims talk, but the speech bubbles generally show what they are talking about or what they need. All of the indicators in game have a visual component, such as the need meters, and events in game are visible things.

Subtitles/Text
Because nothing requires subtitles, this section isn't necessary.

Chatting/Communicating
When playing with others, you can communicate by typing, so there are no problems here.

reviewText:
Sims 3 Is an insult not just a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• game

There are two main points to why Sims 3 is a terrible game. Despite the graphical advancements and optimization that make Sims 3 a much smoother game than previous titles, Sims 3 fails to deliver an actually game experience that is rewarding. This and atrocious advertising by EA/Maxis make the game a flop. Here are the reasons broken down.

1) In game advertising. This was such a new low in all my time of playing video games. At every turn, the game is selling you something more. IN THE GAME!!! And if its not useless then its obviously removed from the final product. Selling 20 DLC is one thing (that I object to FYI) but selling you furniture in the game building menu, loading screens that were for DLC, and then asking you to post your screen shots on Facebook... wow that is just putrid. Your playing of the Sims 3 is not a game, but an extended infomercial.

2) I simply found Sims 3 to be a series of mini-games rolled into one. Career advancement, needs, lifetime aspirations, friendships, it was all just so boring to check off one task after another to satisfy each 'aspect' of the game. None of these things made a difference with each other.

Dont go to the bathroom and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• yourself? no worries, this has no affect with the sim you're talking to. Cheat on your sim significant other? who cares, you'll still get a promotion at work. Achieve the lifetime aspiration? not a bid deal, since you'll get one more pointless talk bubble with another sim that wont mean anything.

Its just frustrating to see that the game has so many aspects that play like mini-games since they have no bearing on anything else. You'd think a close sim dying would remove options for your playing sim since a traumatic death would scare/encourage certain developments. Nope

Also failure in the game means nothing. Got rejected from WooHoo? Got fired? Got a sim cheating on you? this will not hinder or alter the game for your sim‚Äôs life. How can this be a game mechanic for success?

If you are of the perspective that in game sales aren‚Äôt a big deal, well then this failure of gameplay can‚Äôt be ignored. What a sad story this franchise has had, going from on eof the most popular games out there (16 million units sold for Sims 1) to a laughing stock example of DLC cash cows.

I'm sure this review is irrelevant now, seeing the Sims 4 being pushed heavily, yes you called it, in the Sims 3 game right now. I waited for Sims 3 to hit rock bottom retail price since I only really wanted the housing design aspect. But having enjoyed Sims 1 and Sims 2 for the game itself, I am disheartenly justified in waiting so long to get this game at 80% off.

reviewText:
Definately would recommend if you're into simulation/real life kind of games.
Its got a nice range of customisation for your own personal needs - ie: Real Life vs Fantasy  (That chick/guy who friendzoned you - No more with this game. You can make her/him fall in love with you. You can drown her/him or even set her/him on fire! [DO NOT do this in real life])   OR Build your own mansion master piece, town etc.
You dont have muscles? This game will give you muscles! Dont have big coconuts? No worries - slide the bust meter all the way up!

This is a game that you can play until you get over it but then be able to come back and pick up where you left off or start over from scratch.
I bought Sims 3 + Multiple DLC packs for $80 (RRP was roughly $200) a few years ago and I dont regret it. Even though it sits there for a while collecting virtual dust due to it becoming repetitive and stale - I am currently back into it. I grab the DLCs while on sale and the additions keep it fresh, interesting and a good variety!
PS: You can complain about the price of the DLC all you want or you could actually be patient and wait til it goes on sale and buy it then... Duh.

reviewText: Sims 3 is a very good game, from its financial teachings of life to its teaching on the stages of life, and eventually death. It also teaches about the Career Ladder, of which many workplaces may have, depending on your skills (which is also implied on the game) and if you have a healthy relationship with colleagues. On top of the fact that this game is educational, its very enjoyable and has its cool and humourus moments, which the game can automatically allow you to save and remember them. There are many aspects on which I find halarious, from the reaction to a fire, and the most saddest parts, like an old sim passing on.\n\nDespite an all round brilliant game in its graphics, which comes to my concern, it requires a very fast processor, one that most of the cheaper computers won't be able to handle, like mine. So therefore the last time I played it, it completely disheartened my gameplay experience as my computer was unable to cope and crashed many times. But, well done anyway EA, well done!

reviewText:
Pros: There's lots of customization available to you as you create your sims, both in looks and personality, so you can easily and creepily recreate your old uncle Frank and live out his life if you really wanted to... Their AI isn't horrible, and they will self-perserve as best as possible without your input (although they're still horrible at it). There are also a lot more interactions with the world and other sims that help flesh out your little community.

Cons: You need the DLCs. Maybe not all of them, but you need at least one of the larger expansions and a few content packs. The base game is okay, but it's obvious that a lot of things that should have been in the base game, such as modifications and extra options for various careers, were not in specifically so EA could sell it to you later. And as always, the more add-ons you have, the worse the game performs, so there's always this balancing act.

Pro?Con?: You will wonder where the last 8 hours of your day went... frequently.

Verdict: I can only recommend this game earnestly if you are okay with buying some of the DLC. If not, then you're in for maybe 15 hours or so of enjoyment before you get bored of having the same items, doing the same careeers, and generally following the same path over and over again.

reviewText:
I have more hours than steam says i do. steam stopped tracking my hours but i had about a thousand hours on origin. This game is addicting and for a period of time, took over my life. The sims allows you to do whatever you want with people. I usually make OTPs and ships on the sims or my friends when they date irl. When one breaks up with someone irl i kill their sim. this is game super fun and expansion packs make it better. although i wish expansion packs were cheaper. You can do almost anything in Sims 3. One expansion pack that is my favorite and that I highly reccomend is Generations, I love playing as families on Sims 3 so this expansion pack was perfect. It adds so much to the game. It adds a new trait, new things you can interact with sims and also imaginary friends which is super fun. It also adds many more useful items like potions. Pets is also a very good expansion pack but I find i crash sometimes when i use it so save often. Pets adds, well pets and other animals that you can collect. it also adds new traits like the Cat Lover, Dog Lover, Animal Lover and etc..

Here are some expansion packs i reccomend you buy at your own risk:

1. Island Paradise

I bought this pack a few months ago and it was so cool, there were boats and houseboats and even a new neighborhood! There was so much more too, hot tubs and resorts there was so much that i cant even begin to tell you. Thats probably one of the things that causes the problem. The problem is that the game lags really badly and crashes every 15 minutes sometimes less. Its probably because of all the stuff in it. The expansion pack would definatly be my absolute favorite if it werent for the lag and crashing

2. Supernatural

Its cool and all with the different creatures but it takes over your game. Thats really all I have to say


Those are the only two I really reccomend looking out for but consider I have not bought all the expansion packs considering how steam has a summer sale once a year and how I am broke most of the time. Thank you for reading this review I know i went off topic kinda but i do that alot

reviewText:
In some ways, this game isn't realistic enough.  I have an Irish wolfhound, and a burglar broke into my house and stole my things, all without a peep out of the dog!  Seriously?!  The dog had already been told to guard the house several times - which let's face it, you wouldn't have to do with a real dog, especially a breed like this, we're not talking chihauha here!  The dog should be programmed to automatically guard, and the burglar should be afraid of it.  Also, your dog runs away if you only feed it for a couple of days or so, and don't hug it, or play with it, or walk it, treat it, brush it ....

In other ways, the game is eerily realistic.  By the time my Sim gets up, showers, brushes her teeth, makes some breakfast, feeds the dog, plays with the dog, hugs/treats/or brushes the dog, takes out the trash, and recycles the newspaper, it's time to go to work.  And my sim only has a part-time job!!  Then she has to come home, make dinner, do the whole dog thing again, maybe find a bit of time to read a skill book, and go to bed.   Way, way, way too much like real life.  Except that I have a full-time job in real life.  Why on earth would I want to play a game that was as filled with mundane tasks and routine as my own life?  People play games to escape from that!

I know, you can change the time speed.  But shouldn't the devs have already set it up as a default that the routine things don't take so long to do, so you don't have to constantly play with the time settings?  and shouldn't they have set it up so your sim knows what to do after you've done the same routine at roughly the same time on the same days, and your sim just goes and does it superfast, leaving you more time to go off and do other things in the game?  am I supposed to set this up, making routine lists and feeding them to my sim?   If I leave my sim alone to do things, she does stupid, pointless things like reading and re-reading Where's Bella, over and over again.

Maybe I just don't know how to play this game, I know it's a popular game, and maybe there's a way around these problems that my 20  hours or so of playing hasn't been enough for me to find.   I get bored quick, though, so if a game can't me interested within that 20 hours, forget it.    Sims3 gets a big thumbs down from me.

reviewText: I really enjoyed playing the base game until I started to invest in the expansion packs.  Stability problems, freezing and random quitting were some of the problems I've experienced.  It's a shame because I've always enjoyed the series.  But it seems that the more expansion packs you add, the more problems seem to show up.  It was running OK for a while when I had just installed Night Life...I only noticed some slowdown here and there.  However, I picked up three expansion packs during the Steam Winter sale.  In doing so, my game became unplayable.  My previous towns were all suddenly gone and any game that I created thereafter always became corrupt.  It's rather frustrating and I wish I could get my money back at this point.  Forums don't seem to be of much help either.  I just had my computer built in Spring 2013 with WIndows 8, so my computer is not the issue.\n\nIn the end, I DO recommend the base game to loyal fans.  However, just be warned that the expansion packs may completely ruin your ability to play, regardless of how new your computer is.  Since the expansion packs are what previously made this game's replayability so high, overall it's a disappointment and I regret having wasted money on broken expansion packs.

reviewText:
What a wonderful game!   It's really fun to play and it's like no other game made ever.   You could easily waste away hours on such a entertaining game.

Why do I not recommend it then you ask?   Easy.   Nothing ever works right.   The developers are more worried about getting the next DLC released so they can get more cash.   They really don't care if all the features in the game or the DLC don't work.  Oh?   You sent our sim to university and then it just vanished making the game unplayable?   Who cares because we already have your money!  Fun stuff.

It's really a shame that we, as consumers, put up with garbage like this.   If a game isn't complete it should not be released as a complete game. Then telling people the new DLC (which cost more money) will fix the problems. Then that DLC causes problems that you have to buy the next DLC to fix.   See what I am getting at?  This game is fun but the people who made it are more worried about coming up with ways to squeeze more money out of you than they are making an enjoyable gaming experience.

When you look at the number of players in the community and the number of DLCs for this game it doesn't take Adam Smith to figure out this title is raking in the cash.  You would think with that kind of money flowing the developers could at least spend a real effort getting rid of the bugs.   After two or three years games should not have bugs that make it totally unplayable.

Ask yourself.   Do I really want to experience the frustration of spending money on something that infuriates me before I get through the registration process?  Am I going to spend money on a game and time creating a sim just to have them vanish when I try to use the extra content?

I wish somebody would file a class action law suite against these guys.  If they had a real threat to their money perhaps then they would start making software that functions as advertised.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Hmm. I am dissapointed and um... angry actually. This is one of the most dissapointing games I have ever played. Not because of gameplay, that part is great... when and if it happens. This is the most buggy thing I have ever played. I read the online reviews which warned me, but I have a great gaming computer with lots of resources and processing power, what could go wrong? My real issue (as far as I can tell) comes from the paradise island add on which consistently stalls and has a huge bug... I tried setting everything down way low but it was still stalling all the time. I would just go elsewhere (like university) and all would be fine, so I mostly played there. But i went on an 'adventure' and when i 'returned home' i got dumped on a tiny island with no ability to move physically at all and I mean at all,  no home no money no access to the other panels for phone or anything else. I have repeatedly gone back to my save and tried again but its the same thing and I can't go anywhere else... the worst part is that when the 'adventure' times out it just takes me there again and I can do no more. When you invest a fair amount of time building a character, which is what sims is all about, and then it gets destroyed by a glitch it really is annoying, and for a game that is this incredibly expensive it's inexcusable. If you still decide to pour your money down this money grubbing hole, don't get paradise island and really look at the forum for issues others are having before considering any other add-ons.  And hey Maxis, when you make a game this badly perhaps you want to take the time to fix it before putting out another rendition. Just sayin.

reviewText:
The Sims 3 is a great experiment in the simulated genre, and it's apparent that it'll stand up against its successors (e.g. Sims 4) it still reeks of the cash-grabbing tactics of EA, with over 20 expansions that just make it a point of overkill unless they're heavily discounted.

If you're a hardcore Sims fan, then you're already going to buy everything, but the fact remains that the create-a-texture option solves a lot of issues that EA would rather you pay money to solve in the form of completely new items.

Sims 3 gets a positive review, but just barely. It's enjoyment is hindered by how bogged down it is with expensive downloadable content that tries to sell itself as essential to an enjoyable experience one moment, and an experiment in caveat empor the next.

reviewText: It's a shame that The Sims 2 isn't available on Steam (and that I seem to recall it having big issues running on later versions of Windows), because that's the best entry in the series. I gave this entry a fair shake, but ultimately didn't like it. My biggest criticism might be that building and designing your house is a thousand times more complicated than the last game, which some people might actually consider a plus. I consider myself to have an obsessive attention to detail, but this game overwhelmed me. Do you want to position your furniture at an angle? What about BETWEEN grid spaces? Do you want to decide the precise shade of every single object in your house? Again, some people might love these new features, but I missed the days when everything snapped to a simple grid and color options were limited. A few constraints allow creativity to blossom, you know? My biggest problem with building and designing, however, is not the overwhelming amount of options but the fact that it just felt less intuitive. In The Sims 2, I knew what all the building tools did and if I had a piece of furniture in mind, I had a pretty good idea where to find it. Not the case with this game. Wait for Sims 4, or go retro.

reviewText:
There's a lot I want to praise this game for. There's tons of sim customization options here, some very powerful building tools, and some pretty funny situations you can get your sims in. Even the pets have a ton of customization options available to them. In truth, when the mood hits me just right The Sims can feel like an incredibly satisfying game. Why can't I recommend this game then?

I have probably over 500 hours clocked into this game on Origin. I have almost all the expansions, and a lot of fun memories with this game. In a lot of ways The Sims is like a seperate hobby branching off of your gaming hobby. The problem is that it's a stupidly expensive hobby for a game and, ultimately, feels like a huge waste of time. No matter what houses or community lots I create or fun families I put together, actually playing the game is often a huge head ache thanks to some pretty miserable pathing choices and unrealistic Sim interactions (why can't they just socialize with the people in the room with them while they are all doing different activities?). I often finding most of my time going into creating new lots for the game, but I have yet to ever make it through an entire generation without the game feeling simply too repetative, unimmersive, or just plain buggy as hell.

There are some fantastic mods that can fix a couple of the issues I've pointed out above, but if you're new to the series bewarned that it is, without a doubt, a huge time sink and a very expensive one at that. Ultimately I think the promises of The Sims 4 has potential to fix many of my peevs with the game, but once again, what an expensive game to get into...

You have been warned.

The sims 3 is a very enjoyable game... WIth the DLC... I mean the core game is fun for the first couple of hours or even the first couple of days but it dries out quickly.

There isn't enough to do in the core game and if you want all the DLC you are going to need to pay approximately $400, I recommend getting the game right now during the flash sale or just when the game is on special so you can enjoy the game a little more.

reviewText:
It actually, actively bothers me that I like this game. Seriously. The Sims is a franchise that has with each new iteration stripped features that used to be free and turned them into expansion packs you have to pay money for, all the while reducing modding capability in favor of trying to nickel-and-dime more stuff out of you to the point that you cannot actually get into the game without getting through a storefront that tries to sell you more things. From a business-practices perspective it's really, really icky and uncomfortable and it makes me feel bad that I still play it.


...but I still play it. God dammit. EA, why are you the only company that makes good life sims. I'm marking this as a no-recommendation not because you shouldn't play it but rather because it's the only way I can rescue any of my dignity.

reviewText:
A game with infinite possibilites but none of them are realized.  So much promise down the drain with this one.
Sims 3 feels like a massive step back from Sims 2: you get less content from the Sims 3 basegame than the Sims 2 basegame...and what Sims 2 was able to do in a handful of DLCs, Sims 3 does with a boatload with each DLC cost at $19-$39.  Ridiculous!

But let's never mind that...the game is seriously broken.  Slow load times, game crashes, frequently corrupted saves, glitches, glitches, glitches, glitches, glitches, glitches, glitches, glitches, glitches...etc!!!!

Hey, EA, how about FIXING your damn game before releasing the next DLC?  It's frustrating to see glitches from 2012 still breaking the game while a million DLCs are being added since that time.  Get off your fat stacks of cash and make the game playable as it's meant to be played, you can't rely on the modding community to fix everything--it's YOUR problem NOT ours.

I give this a 9/10, you should try it for yourselves, if you have not already.

reviewText:
The Sims 3 is a great game. Many people will say that The Sims 2 or The Sims 4 is better. The Sims 3 is the best Sims game because it has open world. I can't imagine a Sims game without open world. Open world allows you to travel to anywhere in the town. After the initial two-three loading screens, the only loading screens you'll encounter are when you use a mirror to change appearance, a dresser to plan outfit, or if you move, and even then these loading screens are quite short. You can customize your Sims fully, with all of the basics and many more clothing, accessories, hairstyles, and outfits available. Whatever you don't have, you can most likely get from The Sims Store, which you need an account for. You use your money to gain SimPoints, the currency used. While The Sims Store is overpriced and it will cost hundreds of dollars to buy all of the items, if you want to make an emo Sim, you will be able to buy all of the emo clothes, haircuts, and furniture without spending too much money.


Enough about The Sims Store. The Sims 3 is great because of the endless possibilities. You can have an amazing variety of Sims, all with different personalities (which are fully customizable,) careers, houses, families, and Lifetime Wishes. The game runs very smoothly on my computer. There are also Skills and Opportunities, somewhat similar to real life. Opportunities will randomly be presented to you, with a brief description of the Opportunity, usually with some humour added in too. Opportunities often require you to do something in exchange for a reward. You may have to visit certain areas, fix broken objects, make food for certain establishments or Sims, or stay in late after work ends. Rewards vary, and may include better relationships with co-workers, bosses, or other Sims, job or school performance, Simoleons (in-game money,) or Skill gain. Opportunities often have a deadline. Skills are like skills in real life. Skills include Writing (typing), Painting, Gardening, Cooking, Handiness, Charisma, and many more. You can build Skills by practicing, which is different for each Skill, or by doing tasks that improve that Skill, as each Skill is useful for a specific task. You can also build Skills by reading books, watching TV channels, learning from other Sims or by having certain Traits.


Overall, The Sims 3 is a good game that has unlimited replayability. It has its cons, however. The same old Sims get boring quickly, as Sunset Valley, the town that comes with the game, always has the same Sims when it is first started. However, the starting Sim's babies and descendants can vary. By creating an account, you get another town for free. A few other cons are that in a household of 8 (the maximum amount) Sims, it is really hard to have fun. You are constantly taking care of their Needs, which are Hunger, Bladder, Hygiene, Fun, Social, and Energy, and the rest of the time you are building Skills or Relationships, or improving job performance. Also, the stuff packs and expansion packs don't add very much, and are overpriced. The Sims Store is also overpriced.

reviewText: Create, build, and explore this fun filled adventure were you control the action. You get to create your very own Sim and build a house or a future for yourself. The options to the creativity in this game are endless. There are so many options to what you can do it can be overwhelming at times. You put attributes into your Sim and you can ether dictate every little action your Sim does or let the Sim make its own decisions. The world is massive and you can interact with pretty much everything. You can be what you want to be and do what you want to do. But with every action there is a equal and opposite reaction so remember that when playing this game. Its such an awesome adventure and a very addictive hard game to put down. Just the details that you can put into your home is mind boggling.  I have totally loved playing and creating in this game. If you like a big world were you control a Sim and control the outcomes to an extent then this is a definite do not miss game! I love it!

reviewText:
I love the Sims 3. I've been playing Sims since Sims 2, and played every expansion pack and game every since!

Pros-
+ I am God
+ Brings back memories of old Sims game
+ Smooth gameplay
+ Simple and easy to learn
+ Fun DLC

Cons-
- DLC is too overpriced
- Takes up a lot of memory (Recommend playing if you have 4+ RAM)
- Price tags on everything
- Some bugs when CAS mode

Love this game, would recommend if your computer is strong enough to handle it, and if you have $100+ cash to spare for DLC.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Oh, the SIMS. The love we dare not speak its name.

I remember playing the original and thinking that it was a lot like a game I had played way, way back in DOS land. Then Sims 2 came out and competely blew my mind, giving a whole new spin on the idea of the virtual dollhouse. It was a game you could walk away from, come back to, watch passively or interfere with. So imagine my surprise when Sims 3 said that the entire town was going to run simultaneously. I was shocked, outraged, and said I wouldn't play it.

I take everything back. The Sims 3 is a solid upgrade to the Sims 2 (though it crashes just as much, it seems) and the up-and-coming Sims 4 still appear to have everything that made the franchise great amounts of money for EA... and people are still waiting in the wings to give them more. Yes, EA, you've taken my money again and I gave it with a smile, a prayer, and a pony.

Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
simulation at it's finest
This game is fun for the whole family. If you have played any of the other sims games then you know what to expect, make a sim (person) give them a job, find them a girlfriend/boyfriend and start a family. The sims 3 really changed alot with the other sims for example the city is now an open world city so not more one lot houses now the city is your lot. There is so many new things involved with the sims 3 that you cant describe it, you need to just jump in the game and find it.

just stunning
You may also notice that the graphics got a smooth upgrade. Sims now look more like real people than worn out dolls. Also your needs such as hunger got an update as well so you dont have to eat and use the bathroom every 5 minuets which gives you more time to explore the city or maybe call up a friend and hang out. There are way more sims in the city than there was in the sims 2 cities which leads to a more realistic tone in the game.

rewards everywhere
As the game is fun you will find that the longer you play the more rewards you can get for example you pay have spent all night at a night club and found some girl to talk to and then later got married to her just to find out she is very famous. Even looking into a telescope at night can be rewarding as you can find new planets and stars and name them and get paid for find them. The game can get a little boring for a while doing the same thing over and over again but anyone who is a die hard fan will love the sims 3.

verdict
The sims 3 is a game where you can do anything and i have not seen anything like it. Even though the game can get borning after awhile its still fun, enjoyable and a great way to pass the time in the real world. I give the sims 3 4/5 stars.

reviewText:
If you like beach parties held indoors  where the bathroom breaks and people use the front lawn as a toilet, feeding random toddlers that aren't your own and sleeping in random beds, then I highly recommend you check out The Sims.

The expansions are a bit of a cash grab though,  in that most of them could have (and should have) been included with the main game.

Beware of the gnomes.

reviewText: Although I only have seven hours on my Steam account, I have spent probably over 500 hours or so on PlayStation 3, Origin, etc. If you're looking for a simulation game, and you don't know what the Sims is, the Sims is by far the best. Create Sims, send them to work, try to upgrade your house, maintain relationships, all are included! It's so addicting, fun, and equally frustrating. It's one of my favorite games, and it runs on almost any computer or laptop! Very highly recommended.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I have been playing The Sims games since the original series of games started in the early 2000's. I love this version the best out of all of them. Not just for the game mechanics or graphics, but because It truly defines the world around the sims in way I have not seen before . In many ways allows more modding than The Sims 2 franchise. They also made it so I wanted to buy the expansions (not necessarily a good thing financially), but that really speaks to me of the quality of this game series in particular because this is something I didn't do with the older versions of the this game series. I feel so comfortable with The Sims 3 I actually have no intention of right a way switching to The Sims 4. I might get it if it on sale next year in Holiday Steam Sale.... but I'm okay with sticking with The Sims 3 for a few more years.

reviewText:
..are there any actual serious reviews for this game? Eh. Here I go.

CONS- DLCs are all the same price- some bring some lackluster minor content, while others bring a whole new game. It depends on the DLC- oh, and not to mention, the game is basically worthless without the Pets DLC. At least, in my personal opinion it is. The only reason I'm not playing the Sims 4 is because there is no Sims 4: Pets released.
- After a certain amount of time, the game lags and freezes up. Sims get stuck on things, and if you can't find out who they are and do the required 'resetSim [firstname] [lastname]' cheat, it'll move at a snail's pace on even the best computer.
- EVEN AFTER YOU MUTE THE DAMN MUSIC, IT STILL BLASTS YOUR EARS EVEN WHEN YOUR VOLUME IS SET TO 10/100. Chill. Music. Music needs to chill, and this bug despartly needs to be fixed. DESPARTLY. Please. Ow. My ears. They are bleeding.
- No, but seriously. There is something wrong with the volume settings. They do not work. At all. The game still blasts your ears.
- Did I mention loading screens? ..No? Well, be prepared to meet them. For thirty minutes at time. Every time you change towns. Every time you go to university. Every time you go to visit china to try to find that stupid thing you can destory bolders with but you NEVER KNOW WHAT IT IS EVEN AFTER HOURS OF PLAYIN--

NEUTRALS= I.. umh. Limited customization options for the pets? Also, if you give your sims high free will they will do nothing but stuff the dog's face full of treats or spam pet the horse. It never ends. N E V E R.
= DLC's are needed to make the game interesting if you aren't doing challenges. Some things should just have been added to the game since they're so minor. Also, where are the patches? No? They've moved onto the Sims 4 without fixing some of these major bugs the game has had since day one? Oh? Really? That's okay. Toootttalllyyy okay.
= Aliens, no. Nobody asked for you. Stop abducting my Sims while I'm trying to spam level my Logic skill to get a promotion. Stop.

PROS+ What the sims is known for: CUSTOMIZATION. You can make your sims as realistic as you want, as crazy as you want, as stupid-looking as you want, as insane as you want, as perfect as you want, as.. well, nearly anything that you want. It's one of the game's core features- to grow and develope the family you have produced over many hours of hardships and learning, only to have things set back or your only sim killed by a meterorite in the lands of China. Yes, that actually happened. Not fun. Not. Fun. Otherwise was okay!
+ Random things. You may only start out with one town and you DO need the DLC's to do most of the interesting things, but otherwise it's pretty grand. If you get the DLCs, say, one every four months, the game actually has a long lifespan. Try to go for 'Generations,' 'Pets,' or 'World Adventures' first. Those are just my personal reccomendations- not even I have all of them yet. Someday. Someday...
+Traits and interactions are fun, and can cause a few good laughs every now and then. Yes, it can be unrealistic- you can get married the same day you enter a steady relationship with someone- but really, it's the Sims. What else do you expect?
+ There's mods for.. just about anything. This game has been modded to hell and back. Plus, on top of that, the amount of challenges this game has(see '100 Baby Challenge,' it's one of the most common ones) causes replayability. Just remember to save!
+ You can bribe Death with a flower.
+ Unlucky sims are basically immortal- they cannot die from any way other than natural causes.
+ Did I hear genertics and hidden traits, anyone?
+ I'm going to add more later, but this is a good game. If you haven't played it already, or seen a video on it.. I'm so, so sorry for whatever rock you've lived under.

reviewText:
I'm writing this review, and cringing at the thought of how much I've spent over the years on expansions as well as other microtransaction crap for this game alone---let ALONE the entire sims series.  I didn't touch Sims 4... but I swear I have a problem. The problem is that I like the ideas behind these games and expansions, and couldn't help but buy that expansion to have my sim live out this crap.

I mean I have robots and zombies flirting at eachother, my neighbor is a plant woman with unicorn, meanwhile my character lives in a trailer and I think might also be a serial flasher.

...I'm giving it a recommend not because of the price, but because I do have fun with this crap.  300 bucks is ridiculous and I'm a stupid, supid man for having payed that over the span of however long on this.

I need better hobbies.

reviewText:
If you'd like to sire a legion of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s and take over a town, play this game.
If you ever wanted to become a president or CEO just by showing up to work, play this game.
If you ever wanted to become best friends with the Grim Reaper, play this game.
If you enjoy in-depth and potentially catastrophic character creation, play this game.
If you want to construct a family more dysfunctional than your real-life one just to watch the drama unfold, play this game.
If you ever wanted to pollute the gene pool of a town with your own genetic code to the point where reproduction between current residents is no longer a viable option, play this game.
If you've never seen someone literally die of embarrassment, play this game.

There are a thousand other reasons to play this game, but if you don't want to deal with the consequences of not micromanaging (or mismanaging) the actions and interactions of your characters, you will probably end up with a lot of dead Sims (which is not necessarily a bad thing).  It's a funny, tongue-in-cheek game with loads of opportunity and replay value; I'd say stay away from the overpriced DLC (and Sims 4, too) until/unless you are totally, irredeemably bored with this one, because the base game alone provides plenty of traits, jobs, skills, etc. to keep you busy for a while.  The base town with the same cast of NPCs does start to get dull after a while, but you probably only need one or two DLC towns at most and if you don't wanna pay, then you can create your own town with your own people.  If you have a decent/recent PC, it should run fine -- a little laggy, but nothing that destroys the experience.

One of my personal all-time favorites; it's not a perfect game, but if you enjoy dicking around with other people's lives and relationships, you will not be disappointed.

10/10 would forget to go to my own wedding/first childbirth again

reviewText: Been meaning to write a little review for a couple of years now and finally i can. Having played the Sims from day one i have watched the Sims evolve over the years and each game is more and more fun to play. You can play the game properly and try and achieve your Sims needs or if your feeling chaotic like myself at times you can create families and just cause havoc and watch them fall apart in messy households running riot. Its also a game my girlfriend and myself can play at the same time, i make the money and do all the hard part and she spends it on customizing parts of the house and garden or buys the next sized house for us to do up haha. There are many many DLC packs for the Sims 3, some that are fun and others that wouldnt interest me but thats ultimately down to personal choice. Sims 3 and Sims pets is all we need to have a laugh for a few hours here and there! Looking forward to the Sims4. I hope this helps some of you that may be considering buying this, any more questions feel free to message me! Peace

reviewText:
If you want a Sims game, but don't want.. as many loading times, this is the one you want.

The Sims 3 was around a long time. Building on the Wishes mechanic of the second game, this one has Lifetime Rewards, where you can gain points for keeping moodlets high and fufilling their various desires.
These points can be cashed in at any point.

Personally, I recommend getting the Supernatural and Late Night expansion packs if you like cities, and like an easier way to be immortal but still allow aging. Being a vampire is pretty fun.
Late Night adds a small city to play in, which admittedly feels a bit... empty. You'll want to play custom towns off the Sims3modding website.

Beyond that... Sims 3 is a mostly open world, non-instanced Sims game. It has problems, sure, it's buggy, it can do a lot of things at once meaning when you save your game it takes forever, you will find horses hanging around a single empty lot if you have pets.
Also, don't get seasons: much of the weather effects are really resource intensive and may kill your game.

reviewText:
The Sims 3 has introduced a touch more realism to the game via updated graphics, for me the graphics are a little 'too' realistic. The cartoony element of the game is what made me fall in love with it's predecessor The Sims 2.

There is extreme creative control with regards to customisation and open-world gameplay.
This is not to say that build-mode is simple, however. Certain aspects are likely to cause irritation.

Gameplay style has ironed out many old flaws from S2, but as usual there are plenty of new bugs!

Despite The Sims 2 being my continued favourite for the series due to the incorporated storylines, The Sims 3 leaves most to the imagination. If played with all expansion packs it only enhances entertainment.

Overall, I really enjoy this game. I would recommend to any Sims fan.

reviewText: I used to be a huge fan of this series, and I kind of have a love-hate relationship with it. I can even remember watching my mother playing Sims 1 when I was like, three. When I played Sims 2, I owned every EP. I once was able to call this my absolute favorite series, until I came to the realization that the game plus all the expansion packs cost around $400, and as amazing as the game is, I don‚Äôt think $400 is worth it. It‚Äôs extremely difficult to play this game and not drool over the expansion packs, so I just kind of stopped playing it. I recommend this game if you have amazing self-control, or have $400 to waste. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, hours of fun are to be had with this excellent game, but the fact is that the developers and publishers are evil when it comes to the EPs. Even though playing as a vampire fireman who aspires to be a stunt double, living with robots, racists, and poodles, then watching them all try to kill each other is amazing, $400 for the full experience? ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you EA.

reviewText:
The Sims 3:

Positives:

+ Purchase a house for your family or build and design your own with hundreds of customisation options. Buy pools, spas, outdoor living areas, decorative garden plants, televisions, exercise machines, kitchen appliances, cars....the list is huge!
+ Work as a master criminal, a journalist or even a detective. Go travelling to...Egypt, France and China (with DLC). This game is packed with plenty to do.
+ Many different skills for your sims to level up, from science to cooking. So you can have a very varied gameplay experience.
+ Several neighbourhoods to play in, each with a unique layout.
+ There's a large amount of playtime in the Sims 3 for players of all sorts. I managed to get about 100 hours out of it.

Negatives:

- While I acknowledge graphics aren't a major focus of Sims gameplay, it could definitely be improved. Aesthetically, this game is disappointing.
- Despite the vastness of Sims 3, it can become boring after awhile. Once you're earning a high wage, built a mansion filled with valuable items and had a family, there's really not much else to do. This game has a cycle of repetition, whereby you continue to do the same tasks over and over, just in different ways. Sure, the kids in your family grow up and you're able to control their lives, but it's like starting from scratch again, where's the sense of accomplishment in that? It's the balance between fun and repetitive content which Sims 3 suffers from.
- The game is quite expensive, even though it's now 5 years old (as of 02/03/2014). DLC is also pricey, so make sure you absolutely want this game before paying in full, or wait for a sale.

Overall Score: 7/10

The Sims 3 is a nice, relaxing game with many interesting features. For fans of the series, it's really worth checking it out. For those that are new to the game, I recommend grabbing this too, but just be aware of the flaws prior to purchase.

reviewText: I must say that I do love the Sims as a franchise. And yes, I will admit that having to pay for multiple little cool things in a game is a horrible idea. But the base game alone is worth adding to your collection of games. It is a unique simulation and can provide some expirimental, time-wasting fun. And it also provides a great base for the modding communtiy to get their creativity on. But without the mods or certain expansion packs, I must admit that it is a very lack-luster and thinly spread game. Comparing the base game to either a modded game or a game with all of the expansions and stuff packs"
date: it is an overly-simply good idea than anything else. Creativity is at play
recommended: yet the microtransactions are strong in this one. I'd make sure to download many mods and to turn off the in-game payment system in the Options to get a very true and personal experience with this fun simulator."
