reviewText:
Twilight begins with an unnamed narrator (whom we later find out is Bella) giving a brief account about how she is about to die at the hands of a hunter. She is dying in the place of someone she loves, and the narrator does not regret any of the choices that brought her to this point. The past few months have been extraordinary, and she can‚Äôt complain.

Zip! Now we‚Äôre following the life of Isabella ‚ÄúBella‚Äù Swan, our seventeen-year-old narrator. Bella is moving to Forks, Washington, to live with her dad. We later learn that she volunteered to do this so that she wouldn‚Äôt hold her mother back from spending more time with her mother‚Äôs new husband. Forks is isolated, cold, dreary, and wet, and Bella‚Äôs relationship with her dad is distant, since she was raised by her mother in Phoenix. Bella's new life is dull until she gets a glimpse of the Cullen family ‚Äì five gorgeous, mesmerizing siblings who attend her high school. She learns they do not socialize with anyone but each other. One of the boys in particular, Edward, pays her close attention and seems to regard her with alarming hostility when she's forced to sit next to him in Biology class. The next day, he is absent from school.

Bella continues to adapt to her new life in Forks. She gets a lot more attention from boys than she was used to in Phoenix. She makes several friends quickly. A few days later, Edward finally is back in school. Now he‚Äôs friendly to Bella. His mere presence excites her. That afternoon in the school parking lot, a boy‚Äôs truck almost hits Bella after skidding on some black ice, but Edward uses his body as a shield in order to save her. Wait, how‚Äôd he do that?! Bella is totally baffled by this, but Edward refuses to explain his inhuman strength. She begins to have dreams about Edward, but at school, he gives her the cold shoulder. His behavior is very confusing, indeed.

Bella gets asked to the upcoming school dance by not one, but three boys, all of whom she rejects. The next day, Edward gets Bella to talk to him during lunch ‚Äì for the first time he‚Äôs spending lunch apart from his siblings. Knowing that she's trying to make sense of his strength and how he saved her, Edward asks for her ‚Äútheories‚Äù on him. Next, it‚Äôs let‚Äôs-figure-out-your-blood-type day in Biology class, and Edward‚Äôs skipping class. Bella becomes faint at the mere thought of blood, and gets taken to the nurse‚Äôs office (Edward appears outside and intercepts her from Mike, one of the guys who has a crush on Bella). Edward insists that he take her home.

That weekend, during a trip to a beach at La Push Indian reservation, Bella meets Jacob Black, who tells her about ‚Äúthe cold ones‚Äù (vampires). Word around the reservation is that the Cullens are vampires. When Bella gets home, she does some internet research and things start falling into place. Bella decides that she‚Äôs too in love with Edward to resist him, even if he is a vampire.

Soon after, Bella takes a trip to Port Angeles with a few friends, where she gets lost looking for a bookstore. Some thugs almost attack her in a dark alley, but Edward appears in his shiny Volvo and saves her. They have dinner together, and he drives her home. He reveals that yes, he is a vampire. Edward doesn‚Äôt want to be a monster, though, and actually only drinks the blood of animals. Bella knows now that he does thirst for her blood, yet she still is in love with him. Edward repeatedly warns Bella that she should be afraid of him and stay away, if she‚Äôs smart.

Edward and Bella take a mini-field trip together and spend the afternoon in a nearby secluded meadow, where Edward shows Bella that his skin sparkles in the sun (which is why vampires only come out at night or on cloudy days, which are common in Forks). They are completely in love. They kiss for the first time. Bella learns more about Edward‚Äôs family and their past. Edward struggles with abiding his morals (not tempting himself by getting close to a human) versus what he desires ‚Äì to be near Bella.

Edward spends the night in Bella's bedroom, watching over her as she sleeps (without her dad knowing, of course). Bella visits Edward‚Äôs house, meets his family, and learns more about their ‚Äúkind‚Äù ‚Äì vampires who don‚Äôt feast on humans. They go back to her house where Jacob and his father Billy Black show up to see her dad (Billy and Charlie are friends). Being a Quileute elder from the La Push reservation, Billy knows about the Cullens' secret and is worried for Bella's safety. He warns her to stay away from the Cullens. After the Blacks leave, Edward returns in his brother's jeep to pick up Bella. They‚Äôre going to play baseball. It's a Cullen family bonding ritual, evidently.

While the Cullens are playing their crazy version of baseball (they're all incredibly strong and fast), three other vampires show up. One named James takes a liking to Bella (in the ‚ÄúI want to eat you‚Äù kind of way). Edward and his family get Bella away from James long enough to make a plan. They know that James is trying to track Bella, so Alice and Jasper (Edward's adoptive siblings) whisk her away to a hiding place in Phoenix, but James lures Bella to him by telling her that he has captured her mom. He‚Äôs about to kill Bella when the Cullen clan shows up. The only problem is that James has already bitten Bella. If Edward doesn't suck the venom-infected blood out of her, she'll become a vampire. Though it's difficult for Edward to control his urge to suck all of Bella's blood, he manages to cure Bella without killing her. The Cullens kill James and get Bella to a hospital, where she starts to recover from her many injuries.

Overall Bella‚Äôs OK, though banged up. She and Edward are more in love than ever. However, they argue because Bella wants him to bite her and make her into a vampire so that they can live together forever; Edward refuses. Regardless of their different species, they are devoted to one another completely.

In the Epilogue, Edward surprises Bella by taking her to the prom ‚Äì she's horrified because she's uncoordinated and worried about dancing in public. Jacob shows up at the dance and delivers a message ‚Äì Billy wants Bella to dump Edward. He also wants her to know that they ‚Äúwill be watching‚Äù (Epilogue.118). Anyway, Edward and Bella go outside to have some time alone ‚Äì it‚Äôs twilight outside. Again, Bella asks Edward to make her into a vampire, and he refuses. Edward says to Bella, ‚ÄúI will stay with you ‚Äì isn‚Äôt that enough?‚Äù and she replies, ‚ÄúEnough for now‚Äù (Epilogue.204).

reviewText:
Good, but damned expensive.  Especially considering:
‚àô The game is relatively ancient.
‚àô They're getting set to release a new version of the game.
‚àô As soon as this version was released, they literally turned off support for the last version of the game.

I play the game like an RPG.  Subsequently, I end up working to keep my character young
date:
even as the world ages around her.

The game allows for an immense amount of freedom, and has very interesting content.

Unfortunately, for a game that costs as much as this one does, they seem to have some pretty big major oversights:
‚àô They have a micro-transaction system that isn't micro and requires buying points.
‚àô Their in-game store does not work with the Steam Wallet.
‚àô Some of the expensive content in their store could well - and probably should - be offered on Steam as DLC instead of from their store.
‚àô The game should have Steam Workshop integration.
‚àô They have a free toolset that will not work with the Steam version - unless  you're willing to edit your registry and perform a wide variety of other advanced tasks in order to trick it.
‚àô The game has some pretty basic bugs, and have always had those bugs, and requires mods just to keep the game playable.

Please note most of the problems I've noted just wouldn't be problems" if the game wasn't still so expensive.  For example:
‚àô Simply releasing a version of the game with all the content available for it included in the purchase price
recommended: even at a cost of around forty dollars
hoursPlayed: would render my complaints null.\n‚àô Either making the base game "free" as in beer
voteText: and bringing the costs of the DLC down to no more than a few dollars each."

reviewText:
The Sims 2 is my favorite Sims version, hands down. I have sunk in a lot of hours on that clunker on how much IMPROVEMENT it had over the Original Sims and it's console counterparts. It introduces Aging, towns, the Supernatural, 3D archetecture, Floors, and just...so much stuff that it is hard to comphrend how many things it has done.
Sims 3, however...isn't that. It kinda...uhm...isn't really as fun.

Sims 3 looks and runs a LOT better than Sims 2, don't get me wrong. The visual design works in it's favor of making characters look realistic as well as adding a town that doesn't require a long-crack loading screen. But when I bought Sims 3 and started playing it, It felt empty rather than full.

Not once did I actually play the In-Game families, when in Sims 2 I took a big love of the single mom and her dedicated son, the three dudes and the little alien baby (...Just got that reference) And the Goth Family just being cool again. But with Sims 3, I cannot recollect a single memorable sim that just made me think: Yeah
date: that WAS a fun family to play with". But...I GUESS you can play as a custom sim? You know
recommended: the one with only a dozen or two default hairstyles?\n\nAnd let's get it out of the way. The Sims is just a dollhouse simulator for adults and kids
hoursPlayed: and we just like building our little 'family' to play around with. But with Sims 3
voteText: it feels more like a Lego simulator

reviewText:
Good, but damned expensive.  Especially considering:
‚àô The game is relatively ancient.
‚àô They're getting set to release a new version of the game.
‚àô As soon as this version was released, they literally turned off support for the last version of the game.

I play the game like an RPG.  Subsequently, I end up working to keep my character young
date:
even as the world ages around her.

The game allows for an immense amount of freedom, and has very interesting content.

Unfortunately, for a game that costs as much as this one does, they seem to have some pretty big major oversights:
‚àô They have a micro-transaction system that isn't micro and requires buying points.
‚àô Their in-game store does not work with the Steam Wallet.
‚àô Some of the expensive content in their store could well - and probably should - be offered on Steam as DLC instead of from their store.
‚àô The game should have Steam Workshop integration.
‚àô They have a free toolset that will not work with the Steam version - unless  you're willing to edit your registry and perform a wide variety of other advanced tasks in order to trick it.
‚àô The game has some pretty basic bugs, and have always had those bugs, and requires mods just to keep the game playable.

Please note most of the problems I've noted just wouldn't be problems" if the game wasn't still so expensive.  For example:
‚àô Simply releasing a version of the game with all the content available for it included in the purchase price
recommended: even at a cost of around forty dollars
hoursPlayed: would render my complaints null.\n‚àô Either making the base game "free" as in beer
voteText: and bringing the costs of the DLC down to no more than a few dollars each."

reviewText:
Honestly i dont know where to begin with this. So ill describe this games awesomeness with my character Mowgli Mann.

Mowgli is a simple member of the Mann family, he sports his massive hunk of black fat and muscle. He's got a fountain in his front yard that he installed because he could, despite his inability to afford property taxes. Besides wanting to become the emperer of all evil, he spends a lot of his time with the most fked sleep schedule any human being could have. Has breakfeast at 1Am and has to sleep at 6pm, despite needing to go to work at 7pm. He always jumps into the car pool car smelling like a pile of sht. His house possess no toilet, only a urinal, so when he needs to go number 2 he has to run to the public pool across town to use the stall. After nearly burning his house down twice with similar freak spagetti cooking accidents, and the consistensy of the repo man breaking into his house and stealing the tv, Mowgli decided to move to another location. This location" was a two story mansion that had a lazy river on the side of it. A lazy river Mowgli can swim in to escape his crippling debt.

After a long while Mowgli eventually made bank. Once he became the emperor of all evil and also owned half the real estate in the city he was able to buy his mansion back again. He lost the house twice. After settling down Mowgli set his eyes on a new prize. He was three doors down from the single moms home. For some reason single moms put blasting radio on all the time

reviewText:
If price is something you can handle, it's well worth the expansion packs.

There's a lot in this game that I haven't personally done.  Spent most of my time building up a character with a huge range of relationships with people.  Lost that one to a bug, but kept on keeping on.  Now I'm back to where I was again and still am enjoying playing the game.

Also, locked everyone but myself out of a fraternity, took everything and sold them for some delicious simoleons.  All this was followed by seeing every single person at the fraternity dropping dead outside the dorm.  BEST CULT SUICIDE EVER.

reviewText: I've always been a Sims fan. All the way back with Sims 1. Lots of endless fun, especially if you get yourself some of the DLC. There's always a lot of DLC for each Sims edition, but one can definitely have fun with just one or two expansions, or just sticking with the base version. Certainly keep an eye on the sales. That's when you'll want to buy new Sims packs. Also, you definitely want to make sure you computer is above the Recommended System Requirements, because the Sims can be very resource-demanding. All that said, it's a great game, and I've never been bored with it! (My Hours Played" is a drop in the bucket when you consider how much I played the game
recommended: before it was on Steam... lol)"
